title: E0391 (cycle detected): error message overly complicated, should be more similar to "let" example

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-verbose
labels.description: Too much output caused by a single piece of incorrect code

body:
````rust
fn main() {
const A: i32 = 4;
const B: i32 = 5;
const C: i32 = B + C; // should be "+ A"
}
````

In this example "+C" should be "+A"  but the error message seems overly complicated to me:
````
Standard Error

   Compiling playground v0.0.1 (/playground)
error[E0391]: cycle detected when const checking if rvalue is promotable to static `main::C`
 --> src/main.rs:7:1
  |
7 | const C: i32 = B + C;
  | ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  |
note: ...which requires checking which parts of `main::C` are promotable to static...
 --> src/main.rs:7:20
  |
7 | const C: i32 = B + C;
  |                    ^
  = note: ...which again requires const checking if rvalue is promotable to static `main::C`, completing the cycle
  = note: cycle used when running analysis passes on this crate
````

When I use `let` instead of `const`, the compiler correctly diagnoses the underlying problem and the error message is much clearer:
````rust
fn main() {
const A: i32 = 4;
const B: i32 = 5;
let C: i32 = B + C;
}
````
````
error[E0425]: cannot find value `C` in this scope
 --> src/main.rs:6:18
  |
6 | let C: i32 = B + C;
  |                  ^ help: a constant with a similar name exists: `A`

error: aborting due to previous error
````
